event: 1783 - General George Washington issues his farewell orders to the Continental Army as the American Revolutionary War officially comes to an end.
1979 - The Iran hostage crisis begins as Iranian militants storm the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, seizing 66 American diplomats and citizens.
1940 - Franklin D. Roosevelt is elected to an unprecedented third term as President of the United States, leading the country through most of World War II.
1942 - The Carlson's patrol, also known as the Long Patrol, begins during the Guadalcanal Campaign. U.S. Marine Raiders harass Japanese forces for 30 days behind enemy lines.
1811 - The Battle of Tippecanoe is fought between U.S. forces led by Governor William Henry Harrison and Native American warriors associated with Shawnee leader Tecumseh.
1942 - Operation Torch begins as American and British forces land in French North Africa, marking the first major U.S. amphibious assault in the European-North African Theater of WWII.
1989 - The Berlin Wall, a symbol of the Cold War, is opened, leading to the reunification of Germany and the collapse of communist regimes across Eastern Europe.
1775 - The Continental Congress passes a resolution to create two battalions of Marines, establishing what would become the United States Marine Corps.
1918 - An armistice is signed between the Allies and Germany, ending the fighting of World War I on the Western Front. The day is now observed as Veterans Day in the U.S.
1942 - The Naval Battle of Guadalcanal begins, a decisive four-day engagement that thwarts Japan's attempt to retake Henderson Field and marks a turning point in the Pacific War.
2001 - In response to the 9/11 attacks, President George W. Bush signs an executive order allowing for military tribunals against any foreigners suspected of terrorism.
1965 - The Battle of Ia Drang begins in Vietnam. It is the first major battle between the U.S. Army and the People's Army of Vietnam and marks the first large-scale use of helicopter air assault.
1969 - In Washington, D.C., the Moratorium to End the War in Vietnam draws an estimated 500,000 demonstrators in one of the largest anti-war protests in U.S. history.
1945 - The U.S. secretly brings 88 German scientists to America to assist in the development of rocket technology, a program known as Operation Paperclip.
1871 - The National Rifle Association (NRA) is founded by two Union Civil War veterans to 'promote and encourage rifle shooting on a scientific basis.'
1987 - The congressional Iran-Contra committees issue their final report, concluding that President Ronald Reagan bore 'ultimate responsibility' for the covert arms-for-hostages affair.
1863 - President Abraham Lincoln delivers the Gettysburg Address at the dedication of the Soldiers' National Cemetery in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania.
1945 - The Nuremberg trials begin, where 24 high-ranking Nazi officials are tried for war crimes by the International Military Tribunal.
1970 - A joint U.S. special operations force conducts the Sơn Tây prison camp raid in North Vietnam in an attempt to rescue American prisoners of war.
1963 - President John F. Kennedy is assassinated in Dallas, Texas, a pivotal moment in U.S. history that leads to Lyndon B. Johnson becoming president.
1943 - The Battle of Makin, part of the Gilbert and Marshall Islands campaign in the Pacific, ends with American forces securing the atoll from the Japanese.
1944 - During World War II, 88 American B-29 bombers raid Tokyo for the first time, using the captured island of Saipan as a base.
1950 - The Chinese People's Volunteer Army launches its Second Phase Offensive in the Korean War, resulting in a major setback for United Nations forces.
1941 - The Japanese First Air Fleet, an aircraft carrier strike force, departs from Hitokappu Bay for its attack on Pearl Harbor.

1942 - At the Battle of the Pips off the coast of Guadalcanal, the U.S. Navy mistakenly engages what they believe to be a Japanese fleet, firing upon radar echoes that are likely just flocks of birds.

1943 - The Tehran Conference begins, where U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, and Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin meet to discuss Allied strategy against Nazi Germany.
1864 - A 675-man force of the Third Colorado Cavalry attacks a peaceful village of Cheyenne and Arapaho people, resulting in the Sand Creek Massacre.
1782 - The United States and Great Britain sign preliminary peace articles in Paris, setting the stage for the formal end of the American Revolutionary War.
